infodynamics.measures.discrete

Class ConditionalMutualInformationCalculatorDiscrete

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.discrete.InfoMeasureCalculatorDiscrete
      • infodynamics.measures.discrete.ConditionalMutualInformationCalculatorDiscrete
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AnalyticNullDistributionComputer

    public class ConditionalMutualInformationCalculatorDiscrete
extends InfoMeasureCalculatorDiscrete
implements AnalyticNullDistributionComputer

    Conditional Mutual information (MI) calculator for univariate discrete (int[]) data.

    Usage of the class is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator: ConditionalMutualInformationCalculatorDiscrete(int, int, int);
    2. Initialise the calculator using initialise();
    3. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using one or more calls to sets of addObservations(int[], int[], int[]) methods, then
    4. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average MI: computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • local MI values, such as computeLocalFromPreviousObservations(int[], int[], int[]);
      • comparison to null distribution, such as computeSignificance();
      • and variants of these.
    5. As an alternative to steps 3 and 4, the user may undertake standalone computation from a single set of observations, via e.g.: computeLocal(int[], int[], int[]).
    6. Return to step 2 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.

    References:

    • T. M. Cover and J. A. Thomas, 'Elements of Information Theory' (John Wiley & Sons, New York, 1991).
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations(int[][] var1,
                   int[][] var2,
                   int[][] cond)
        Add observations for the given var1,var2,cond tuples of the variables to our estimates of the pdfs. This method signature allows multiple trials to have their observations added to the PDFs by one method call.
        Parameters:
        var1 - series of values for the first variable; first index is time or observation number, second index is trial (a second observation number if you will)
        var2 - series of values for the second variable, indexed as per var1
        cond - series of values for the conditional variable, indexed as per var1

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the conditional MI would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value (in the context of the conditional).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI, conditional MI and TE. Note that this method currently fixes the relationship between variable 2 and the conditional, and shuffles variable 1 with respect to these.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(int[], int[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to bootstrap to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the distribution of conditional MI scores under this null hypothesis.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][] newOrderings)
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the conditional MI would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination values.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for a conditional mutual information. Basically, the marginal PDFs of each marginal are preserved, while their joint PDF is destroyed, and the distribution of conditional MI under these conditions is generated. Note that this method currently fixes the relationship between variable 2 and the conditional, and shuffles variable 1 with respect to these.

        TODO Need to alter the method signature to allow callers to specify which variable is shuffled. (Note to self: when doing this, will need to update machine learning code to the new method signature)

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int)) allows the user to specify how to construct the surrogates, such that repeatable results may be obtained.

        Parameters:
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the values of variable 1 to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by InfoMeasureCalculatorDiscrete.getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the distribution of conditional MI scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to the number N samples that were previously supplied.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public AnalyticMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance()
        Description copied from interface: AnalyticNullDistributionComputer
        Generate an analytic distribution of what a given measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value (possibly in the context of a conditional value).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI, conditional MI and TE as per the references below.

        References:

        • J.T. Lizier, "JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems", 2014.
        • Brillinger, "Some data analyses using mutual information", Brazilian Journal of Probability and Statistics, 18, p. 163, (2004)
        • Cheng et al., "Data Information in Contingency Tables: A Fallacy of Hierarchical Loglinear Models", Journal of Data Science, 4, p. 387 (2006).
        • Geweke, "Measurement of Linear Dependence and Feedback between Multiple Time Series", Journal of the American Statistical Association, 77, p. 304-313 (1982).
        • Barnett and Bossomaier, "Transfer Entropy as a Log-likelihood Ratio", Physical Review Letters, 109, p. 138105+ (2012).
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface AnalyticNullDistributionComputer
        Returns:
        the analytic distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
